@gechiang sure, I'll update the PR ASAP. I didn't see an existing file for fans so I was unsure of the requirements. I'll create a file to cover the new fan APIs.

> @spilkey-cisco please provide more context.

The tolerance calculations that thermalctld performed (the defaults in the base file now) were not sufficient for Cisco's fan tolerance requirements. Since the default tolerance checks were required to calculate using fan speed as percentage values (1-100), low fan speeds had a large margin of error, and frequently falsely indicated the fan speed was outside the allowable tolerance. Allowing vendors to specify their own tolerance calculations if desired resolves this issue (such as performing calculations on larger rpm values instead of percentages, as an example), and the default implementation here allows existing vendor code to continue to work with no modifications.

If the code returns None, the current change set will indeed return float(None). I now went through the test logs and it seems that we are indeed running into that situation and hence, the test fails. Please refer to the below for further details.
https://dev.azure.com/mssonic/build/_build/results?buildId=280114&view=logs&j=12f1170f-54f2-53f3-20dd-22fc7dff55f9&t=b24cf96b-e476-5cd6-97ae-776d6935d22f&l=448

> @rajann What is the thought behind selecting to return "0" for "Reserved" values?

This api is already returning 0 for None (which is not expected). In the same line, un-supported values are not expected as well and hence the return is 0

> @liushilongbuaa can you elaborate a bit more why installation from PyPi is security concern?

Because SONiC packages are not registered in PyPi. When we run setuptools, it will try to download from PyPi.
If someone registered packages using the same name. Unsafe code is executed.
